text: As an Indian who lives in India and has observed my own people overseas, I always say that it's as important to adapt to the culture of the nation you live in as it is to remember and stay true to your roots. replies.author: @ithurtsbecauseitstrue
replies.text:
@freedomandguns3231 When someone is shot in the head for saying "all lives matter" - I'd say white are BEYOND marginalized. Many minorities now say: all whites are racist. All whites are evil. 

My ELEMENTARY SCHOOL kid came home crying because the black kids openly said: "all white people are idiots." All three of my kids had gone to this school. So we've been there for two decades. Never had an issue like this occur before. The teachers were upset, and crying about it as well. I know - my wife teaches at the school  and talked directly to them. But they said they didn't know what to do about it. Fine.

I get that.

But if they races were reversed? I bet they'd have some ideas of what to do about it.

Whites are marginalized. By "allies" and by minorities. When companies advocate elevating minority voices, they do that by excluding or diminishing ONE type of voice specifically - an on racial grounds.
When black groups push for more blacks to be in leadership positions in companies - that often doesn't just lead to hiring more... but also to relieving present white employees.

And the most important thing: White are right now only in the earliest stages of this marginalization. You don't tell a group of people "only whites can be racist" for any other reason than to EXCUSE the racism of anyone who is not white. And to excuse racism against whites as okay. And that allowable racist IS hate. And hate won't go away. Hate will manifest.

A co-worker I know is a recent college graduate. And is black. And has PLENTY of stories to tell about the kids, and discord servers where minorities had no shame in the terrible things they would say about white people. Calling them pigs. Saying they hated them. All without ANY concern of the racism of it.

Marginalization is the least of our concerns. If we don't move away from "equity" and back towards equality - the future won't be mere marginalization. And kicked knees will look like a walk in the park.

text: As a Korean American who was adopted by an American family in the bible belt of America, I grew up conservative but during the election before the last one had me leaning a little to the left. replies.text:
Why are you so pro-diversity? I‚Äôm just curious what you have to say. I grew up in the public school system and was always taught diversity is our strength. When I got to college, my professor my junior year in civil engineering asked me to explain why we were so much better off with diversity. I couldn‚Äôt provide much of an answer and realized that that‚Äôs just what I was always told growing up.
I don‚Äôt care if 100% of people admitted into med school are Asian if they‚Äôre the most deserving. I don‚Äôt care if a school is 100% one race if they have great education standards. I just don‚Äôt care one bit about ones race/background only if they were most deserving and earned it more than anyone else. If it leads to a diverse group, great. If it leads to only white males or only black women, great. I cannot for the life of me understand why diversity is shoved down our throats unless it‚Äôs for nefarious reasons or a way to take power over certain groups or people.

Places like Japan that are 99% of people with Japanese origins have very low crime, murder, civil unrest, etc.. and they‚Äôre one of the least diverse nations in the world.

If diversity was so, so, so great, wouldn‚Äôt countries like Japan be a very undesirable and failure of a country in some kind of way? I can‚Äôt think of anything that they are in the bottom 50% of nations in. Maybe fruit prices. I know fruit can be quite expensive there as nearly all of it has to be imported from other nations. Alright, never mind, there you have it. Japan‚Äôs inability to grow and provide their own fruit will one day be the downfall of their country. That‚Äôs a bummer to hear.
